subject: Re: [junit] Question about Interdependent Test Cases
msgSnippet: It seems the only emails I ever write on this list are regarding this topic. // this is a test public void testJunk() { create(); get(); delete(); } // this is
messageBody:
It seems the only emails I ever write on this list are regarding this
topic.

// this is a test
public void testJunk() {
create();
get();
delete();
}

// this is not a test
public void create() {
if (doStuff() == FAILED)
fail("creation failed");
}

If seems wrong to write them all in one method, that's because it
usually is. If the method doesn't say "test" before it, it will not be
included in the test suite automatically. So, I would recommend you
write your utility methods; they can call assert just like any other
test. Suppose calling delete twice violates your contract, writing
that test becomes pretty simple with these utility methods.

public void testMultipleDeletes {
create();
get();
delete();
try {
delete();
fail();
} catch (Exception e /* should be more specific, of course */) {
}

Only the methods that start with "test" are tests.

-shane

On Monday, June 30, 2003, at 11:29 AM, Leonardo Abreu de Barros wrote:

> Hi all,
>
> I have a simple question about arranging related tests inside a test
> case:
>
> - Let`s say I have three tests that in some way depend on each other:
> for example, a creation, a getter and a deletion method.
> These are distinct functionalities, and thus deserve to be on
> separate tests. The problem is: if one fails, the other two will run
> anyway. But if the creation or getter methods fail, it doesn`t make
> sense for me to test the deletion method, as it depends on the
> correctness of the other two. I know calling one test inside another
> is not recommended. What should I do in this case?
>
